'''Lizzie van Zyl''' (22 April 1894 – 9 May 1901)<ref name="Bloemfontein">{{cite web|url=http://www.lib.uct.ac.za/mss/bccd/Histories/Bloemfontein/|title=British Concentration Camps of the South African War 1900–1902: Bloemfontein|publisher=[[University of Cape Town]]|accessdate=1 April 2012}}</ref><ref name="van Heyningen">{{cite journal|last=van Heyningen|first=Elizabeth|title=A tool for modernisation? The Boer concentration camps of the South African War, 1900–1902|journal=South African Journal of Science|volume=106|issue=5–6|date=8 June 2010|url=http://reference.sabinet.co.za/webx/access/electronic_journals/sajsci/sajsci_v106_n5_6_a17.pdf |accessdate= 13 September 2016}}</ref> was a child inmate of [[Bloemfontein#Second Anglo-Boer War/South African War|Bloemfontein concentration camp]] who died from [[typhoid fever]] during the [[Second Boer War]].<ref name="Bloemfontein"/><ref name="van Heyningen"/><ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last=Godby|first=Michael|date=2010|title=Confronting Horror: Emily Hobhouse and the Concentration Camp Photographs of the South African War|url=http://reference.sabinet.co.za/webx/access/journal_archive/02590190/617.pdf|journal=Department of Historical Studies|volume=University of Cape Town|issue=|doi=|pmid=|access-date=25 August 2016|via=}}</ref>
==Background==
The British incarcerated her in a concentration camp following the refusal of her father, a [[Boer]] combatant, to surrender. Activist [[Emily Hobhouse]] used her death as an example of the hardships the Boer women and children faced in the British concentration camps during the war. She describes Lizzie as "a frail, weak little child in desperate need of good care", who was placed on the lowest rations and, after a month, was moved to the new hospital about {{convert|50|km|mi|abbr=off}} away from the concentration camp, suffering from starvation. Initially the publishers of Hobhouse's reports refused to publish the photograph.<ref name=":0" />
According to Hobhouse, she was treated harshly in the hospital. Unable to speak English, she was labelled an "idiot" by an English-speaking doctor and her nurses, who were unable to understand her. One day she started calling for her mother; a lady went over to comfort her, but "was brusquely interrupted by one of the nurses who told her not to interfere with the child as she was a nuisance." Lizzie died in 1901 at seven years of age.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boer.co.za/boerwar/hellkamp.htm|title=The Concentration Camps|publisher=Boer.co.za|date=21 May 1995|accessdate=3 June 2013}}</ref>
==Photo==
The photo of the emaciated van Zyl reportedly was passed from Scottish author [[Arthur Conan Doyle]], who served as a volunteer doctor during the Boer War, to [[Joseph Chamberlain]].<ref name="lewis">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbctransgenerational.com/articles.html |title=Lizzy van Zyl |author=Hélène Opperman Lewis |accessdate=25 February 2015 }}</ref> Both Doyle and Chamberlain were proponents of the Boer Wars; Doyle wrote a short work ''The War in South Africa: Its Cause and Conduct'', that justified the war.
The photo was used as [[propaganda]], author Hélène Opperman Lewis states, to convince the British public that Boer children were neglected by their parents. The image was released with the detail that it was taken when van Zyl and her mother entered the camp. Chamberlain was quoted in ''[[The Times]]'' on 5 March 1902, saying that Lizzie's mother was prosecuted for mistreatment.<ref name="lewis"/>
Hobhouse investigated the case and was unable to find any evidence of the case or prosecution of Lizzie's mother. She located the photographer, a man named Mr. de Klerk (also a camp inmate at the time),<ref name=":0" /> who confirmed that the photograph was taken two months after Lizzie arrived at the camp.<ref name="lewis"/>
